subject: History
title: Lister's Antiseptic Revolution
description: A short lesson to help you apply Lister's Antiseptic Revolution.

hook.text: In the 1860s, nearly half of surgery patients died from infection. Joseph Lister figured out whyâ€”and how to stop it.

buildup.text: Inspired by Pasteur's germ theory, Lister sprayed carbolic acid on wounds, instruments, and his own hands.

discovery.text: Post-surgical infection rates plummeted. His ward went from a death trap to one of the safest in London.

twist.text: Many surgeons mocked himâ€”they considered dirty coats and bloody aprons as badges of experience.

climax.text: Antiseptic surgery became standard by the 1880s. The operating room transformed from butcher shop to sterile zone.

punchline.text: Clean hands were medicine's hardest sell.

quiz.question: What inspired Lister to develop antiseptic surgical techniques?
options: Pasteur's germ theory linking microorganisms to infection
A visit to Islamic hospitals that practiced hand hygiene
